Package mz

Class SmoothHeap

java.lang.Object
mz.SortComparable
mz.Heap
mz.SmoothHeap
All Implemented Interfaces:
HeapInterface<Comparable>, Sort<Comparable>, SortSwap<Comparable>
Direct Known Subclasses:
IntroSmoothHeap
public class SmoothHeap extends Heap
Smooth Heap Sort it is another version of heapsort that is designed to minimize the number of comparisons performed during the sort. Like heapsort, smooth sort sorts an array by building a heap and repeatedly extracting the maximum element.
Since:
1.0

  • Constructor Details

    • SmoothHeap

      public SmoothHeap()
      Smooth Heap Sort:
      It is another version of heapsort that is designed to minimize the number of comparisons performed during the sort. Like heapsort, smooth sort sorts an array by building a heap and repeatedly extracting the maximum element.

      Example:
      1. The first for loop iterates over the elements of the array. For each element, it adds a new element to a heap structure stored in the array and ensures that the heap property is maintained after the insertion.
      2. After the first loop completes, the buffer contains all the elements from the array in a heap structure.
      3. The second for loop iterates over the indices of the array. For each index i, it calls the deletes the minimum element from a heap structure stored in the buffer array and ensures that the heap property is maintained after the deletion.
      4. At the end, the array will contain the elements sorted in increasing order.
      Note:
      Like Heapsort, Smooth Sort is an in-place algorithm with an upper bound of O(n log(n)), but it is not a stable sort. The advantage of Smooth Sort is that it comes closer to O(n) time if the input is already sorted to some degree, whereas heapsort averages O(n log(n)) regardless of the initial sorted state.

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Best Case Complexity: O(n)
      Average Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Auxiliary Space: O(n)
      Stability: No
      See Also:
      • IntroDPQSmoothHeap
      • IntroSmoothHeap

    • smoothInc

      protected void smoothInc(Comparable[] array)
      smoothInc. This method performs a Smooth Heap Sort on an array of Comparable objects in increasing order. It utilizes the insertInc and deleteMinInc methods to build a heap from the array elements and then extract the elements from the heap in sorted order.
      • The method takes an array of Comparable objects, denoted by array, as a parameter.
      • The variable n is assigned the length of the array.
      • The first for loop iterates over the elements of the array. For each element, it calls the insertInc method to insert the element into the heap represented by the buffer.
      • After the first loop completes, the buffer contains all the elements from the array in a heap structure.
      • The second for loop iterates over the indices of the array. For each index i, it calls the deleteMinInc method to extract the minimum element from the heap and assigns it back to the array[i]. This effectively sorts the elements of the array in increasing order.
      • At the end of the method, the array will contain the elements sorted in increasing order.
      smoothInc method uses the insertInc and deleteMinInc methods to perform a smooth sort on the given array, resulting in the elements being sorted in increasing order.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • insertInc(Comparable)
      • deleteMinInc()

      protected void smoothInc(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      smoothInc. This method performs a Smooth Heap Sort on an array of Comparable objects in increasing order. It utilizes the insertInc and deleteMinInc methods to build a heap from the array elements and then extract the elements from the heap in sorted order.
      • The method takes an array of Comparable objects, denoted by array, as a parameter.
      • The variable right is assigned the length of the array.
      • The first for loop iterates over the elements of the array. For each element, it calls the insertInc method to insert the element into the heap represented by the buffer.
      • After the first loop completes, the buffer contains all the elements from the array in a heap structure.
      • The second for loop iterates over the indices of the array. For each index i, it calls the deleteMinInc method to extract the minimum element from the heap and assigns it back to the array[i]. This effectively sorts the elements of the array in increasing order.

      smoothInc method uses the insertInc and deleteMinInc methods to perform a smooth sort on the given array, resulting in the elements being sorted in increasing order.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - the value in the array must be smaller than a right parameter.
      right - the value in the array must be greater than a left parameter.

    • insertInc

      protected void insertInc(Comparable insert)
      insertInc this method is likely a part of a heap-related algorithm or data structure implementation and is used to insert a new element into a heap structure stored in the buffer array. The method takes a Comparable object called insert as a parameter.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The method starts by inserting the insert element at index size in the buffer array and then increments the size variable. This step adds the new element to the end of the heap structure.
      • The resize method is called to check if the size of the buffer exceeds half of its capacity. If it does, the buffer is resized by doubling its capacity using the expression (buffer.length * 2).
      • The if (size > 1) condition checks if there is more than one element in the buffer. If so, the method enters a loop that continues as long as the current index i is not equal to 0 (the root of the heap).
      • Inside the loop, the variable j is assigned the index of the parent element of the current element at index i, calculated using the expression ((i - 1) / 2).
      • The subsequent if condition buffer[i].compareTo(buffer[j]) < 0 compares the current element at index i with its parent element at index j. If the current element is smaller than its parent, it performs a swap between the elements at indices i and j. After the swap, it updates i to j, allowing the loop to continue comparing and swapping elements with their parents.
      • If the current element is not smaller than its parent, the else block is executed, and the loop is terminated using break, as the heap property is already satisfied.
      insertInc method adds a new element to a heap structure stored in the buffer array and ensures that the heap property is maintained after the insertion. It achieves this by adding the element to the end of the heap, resizing the buffer if necessary, and iteratively comparing and swapping elements with their parents to restore the heap property.
      Parameters:
      insert - starts by inserting the element.
      See Also:
      • resize(int)
      • SortSwap.swap(Comparable[], int, int)

    • insertDec

      protected void insertDec(Comparable insert)
      insertDec this method is likely a part of a heap-related algorithm or data structure implementation and is used to insert a new element into a heap structure stored in the buffer array. The method takes a Comparable object called insert as a parameter.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.

    • deleteMinInc

      protected Comparable deleteMinInc()
      deleteMinInc. This method is likely a part of a heap-related algorithm or data structure implementation and is used to delete the minimum element from a heap structure that is stored in the buffer array. The method returns the deleted minimum element, which is of type Comparable.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The method starts by assigning the value of the element at index 0 in the buffer to the variable result. This represents the minimum element that will be deleted.
      • The size variable is decremented by 1 to reflect the removal of an element from the heap.
      • The swap method is called to exchange the elements at indices 0 and size in the buffer array. This step effectively removes the minimum element from the heap by moving it to the last position in the buffer.
      • The method then enters a loop that continues as long as the left child of the current element at index i ((2 * i) + 1) is within the valid range of the buffer (less than size).
      • Inside the loop, the variable j is assigned the index of the left child of the current element.
      • The subsequent if condition (j + 1) < size && buffer[j].compareTo(buffer[(j + 1)]) > 0 checks if the right child of i exists and is smaller than the left child. If so, j is updated to the index of the right child (j + 1).
      • The next if condition buffer[j].compareTo(buffer[i]) < 0 compares the element at index j (the smaller child) with the element at index i. If the child is smaller, it performs a swap between the elements at indices j and i. After the swap, it updates i to j, allowing the loop to continue the comparisons and swaps downward in the heap structure.
      • If the child is not smaller than the current element, the else block is executed, and the loop is terminated using break, as the heap property is already satisfied.
      • Finally, the method returns the deleted minimum element stored in the result variable.
      deleteMinInc method deletes the minimum element from a heap structure stored in the buffer array and ensures that the heap property is maintained after the deletion. It achieves this by swapping the minimum element with the last element, adjusting the size of the heap, and iteratively comparing and swapping elements to restore the heap property.
      Returns:
      the deleted minimum element stored in the result variable
      See Also:
      • SortSwap.swap(Comparable[], int, int)

    • resize

      protected void resize(int capacity)
      resize this method is used to resize the internal buffer of an object or class that contains an array of Comparable objects. The method takes a capacity parameter to specify the new capacity of the buffer.
      • The code snippet includes two private variables: buffer, which is an array of Comparable objects with an initial size of 256, and size, which represents the number of elements currently stored in the buffer.
      • The resize method is used to adjust the capacity of the buffer based on the provided capacity parameter. It checks if the current size of the buffer is half of the desired capacity.
      • If the condition is met, indicating that the current buffer is utilizing half or more of its capacity, the method creates a new buffer with the specified capacity using the Comparable array type.
      • The System.arraycopy method is then used to copy the existing elements from the current buffer (buffer) to the newly created buffer (newBuffer), up to the current size.
      • Finally, the reference to the new buffer is assigned to the buffer variable, effectively resizing the buffer to the specified capacity.
      resize method ensures that the buffer is resized when the number of elements stored in it reaches half of its capacity. It creates a new buffer with the desired capacity and copies the existing elements from the old buffer to the new buffer.
      Parameters:
      capacity - the new capacity of the buffer
